metadata.case_name: State of Travancore-Cochin v. Cochin Coal Company Ltd.

facts.text: The Cochin Coal Company Ltd. (respondent) are dealers in coal, importing and stocking bunker coal at Candle Island within the State of Madras.
Respondent supplies bunker coal from Candle Island (Madras) to steamers arriving at or calling at Cochin port in Travancore-Cochin for outward voyage.

Procedure: Steamer agents contract with respondent for trimming coal into steamer bunkers; after steamer arrival, agents secure papers from customs/port authorities, take to respondent's office in Fort Cochin (Madras); respondent sends goods via transport contractor; delivery orders release coal from Candle Island; coal taken to steamer in Cochin port (Travancore-Cochin waters); Chief Engineer inspects and permits loading; payment on bills to respondent.
Sales tax claimed on bunker coal sales for assessment years 1951-52 and 1952-53; assessment completed on February 2, 1954 by Sales Tax Officer, Circle, Mattancherry.
Respondent contended no sales tax leviable as sales in course of export (Art. 286(1)(b)) or inter-State trade (Art. 286(2)), exempted.
Sales Tax Officer rejected exemption, held sales inside Travancore-Cochin per Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) as delivery for consumption within State; rejected double taxation argument.
Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed: sales in course of export under Art. 286(1)(b) or exempt by State Government notification dated February 5, 1954.
Deputy Commissioner (Revisional authority) suo motu set aside appellate order, restored Sales Tax Officer order, holding sales inside State.
High Court of Travancore-Cochin under Arts. 226/227 set aside revision order; granted certificate under Art. 133(1).
Notification dated February 5, 1954 (Gazette February 16, 1954) exempted sales by non-resident dealers for delivery/consumption in State prior to April 1, 1953, per s.6 of Sales Tax Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether sales of bunker coal are liable to sales tax under Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125, or exempt under Art. 286(1)(b), Art. 286(2), or Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a), and/or State notification.
Whether sales in course of export out of India under Art. 286(1)(b).
Whether sales in course of inter-State trade under Art. 286(2), saved by Validation Act 1956.
Whether delivery for consumption within State per Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a).

petitioner_arguments.text: Sales inside State per Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a); inter-State ban under Art. 286(2) not applicable or saved by Sales Tax Law Validation Act, 1956; notification not statutory exemption.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(1)(a) Explanation; Sales Tax Law Validation Act, 1956; s.26 Travancore-Cochin Sales Tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Sales in course of export under Art. 286(1)(b) as coal carried outside India; alternatively inter-State under Art. 286(2); or exempt by notification dated February 5, 1954 under s.6.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 286(1)(b), Art. 286(2); s.6 Travancore-Cochin Sales Tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Sales fall within Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) but exempt by notification for period prior to April 1, 1953.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.6 Travancore-Cochin Sales Tax Act; Notification Feb 5, 1954

court_reasoning.text: Transaction in course of inter-State trade, covered by Art. 286(2) ban, but levy validated by Sales Tax Law Validation Act, 1956; High Court's construction of s.26 incorrect per Sundararamier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art. 286(2) relief not available due to Validation Act.

court_reasoning.text: Not in course of export under Art. 286(1)(b) as no destination outside India; mere movement out insufficient per Burmah Shell.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Export requires two termini; bunker coal lacks foreign import destination.

court_reasoning.text: Sale falls within Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a): goods moved from Madras to Travancore-Cochin; delivery in State to ultimate consumer for consumption therein, even if later moved out.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delivery to steamer for its use; consumer free to consume in State or elsewhere does not detract.

court_reasoning.text: Notification dated February 5, 1954 under s.6(1) exempts such inter-State sales treated as intra-State per United Motors, for period before April 1, 1953; applies to respondent's transactions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statutory exemption; State acknowledged in proceedings.

holdings.text: Sales fall within Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) as inside sales; not export or purely inter-State exempt; but exempt by s.6 notification.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. v. State of Bihar
M. P. V. Sundararamier & Co. v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Construction of state sales tax laws re inter-State sales.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burmah Shell Oil Storage & Distributing Co. of India Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Export requires destination outside India; aviation spirit not export.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) makes certain inter-State sales intra-State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Exemptions from state sales tax for export/inter-State sales; Explanation deems certain sales inside state.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to exempt specified sales; no tax on inter-State sales (disputed construction).

statutes_cited.name: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates state levies on inter-State sales.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court order setting aside sales tax assessment; held sales intra-State per Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a) but exempt by notification dated February 5, 1954 under s.6 for relevant period; respondent entitled to exemption.
outcome.relief_granted: No sales tax on bunker coal sales for 1951-52 and 1952-53

key_quotes.text: "the sale of the bunker coal by the assessee-company fell within the Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines sales as intra-State taxable in principle.

key_quotes.text: "the respondent-company would be entitled to the benefit of the tax exemption conferred by the notification."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Grants relief to respondent, dismissing appeal.

key_quotes.text: "in the context and setting in which the expression 'export out of the territory of India' occurs in Part XIII of the Constitution, it was not sufficient that goods were merely moved out of the territory of India but that it was further necessary that the goods should be intended to be transported to a destination beyond India".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects export exemption per Burmah Shell.
